awd_titl_txt: SL-CN: Inter-generational Transfer of Beliefs about Math
awd_abstract_narration:
This Science of Learning Collaborative Network brings together scientists and educators from University of Washington, University of California-Santa Cruz, and partners in Chile to examine the inter-generational transfer of math-gender stereotypes and math self-concepts in K-3 students. A fundamental challenge for the science of learning is to deepen our understanding of why certain academic Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines, but not others, have significant disparities in who chooses to pursue those disciplines. Cultural stereotypes about "who does STEM" have been shown to influence such disparities. The impact of STEM stereotypes has been documented in adults. However, the origins of these stereotypes and their influence early in the STEM 'pipeline' are understudied. Research shows that the elementary school period is a critical time that begins to shape children's interests, motivation, and skills in academic fields. This collaborative network examines the mechanisms of transfer of information within the family environment, and the ways in which this is tied to students' actual math achievement in the classroom. The network is designed to disseminate findings to families, educators, policymakers, and students using a series of workshops and webinars. The network's outreach efforts focus on translating the scientific findings into actionable strategies that teachers can use in their classrooms and parents can use at home, which will shorten the gap between discovery and educational practice.

The network investigates the role of "non-academic" (psychological) factors that influence children's learning of math. The two principal research questions are: (a) the interrelation among child, parent, and teacher stereotypes about math, and (b) how these influence children's developing math self-concepts, their math achievement (grades, test scores), and career interests in STEM. Chile is a particularly important cultural context for investigating how cultural stereotypes serve to discourage math participation/achievement in young children, because it represents a society in which math-gender stereotypes are strong, historically persistent, and amenable to study. The network is highly interdisciplinary, assembling developmental scientists, social psychologists, educators, and community leaders. The network adopts a multi-method approach: (a) combing both implicit (child IAT) and explicit (self-report) measures about "who does math," (b) examining the relative contribution of parent and teacher interactions on children's emerging math identity, and (c) investigating the influence of educational and community contexts (including SES and school characteristics). The network will use the results to teach parents, students, teachers, and communities about the scientific process both in the United States and in Latin America.

The award is from the Science of Learning-Collaborative Networks (SL-CN) Program, with funding from the SBE Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences (BCS), the SBE Office of Multidisciplinary Activities (SMA), and the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

por.por_cntn:
Previous research has shown that children develop gender stereotypes about math (math = boys) by second grade. The current project tested the hypothesis that feelings and beliefs about math can be detected even earlier. The aim of this project was to uncover: (a) how early these attitudes and beliefs about math may form, and (b) what role parents play in the development of children's attitudes and beliefs. Researchers from two US universities partnered with universities in Chile, Croatia, and Spain to perform studies on families' math attitudes and beliefs and how they may be related to children's math achievement.

In one study with Chilean children, we found that 5-year-old boys already held the unconscious ("implicit") stereotype that math = boys. This provided the first evidence that cultural stereotypes about math can be held before elementary-school, and also that stereotypes may emerge earlier for boys than for girls. To investigate the possible sources of these reactions to math, we analyzed several aspects of the family environment: (i) parental stereotypes, (ii) parental self-concepts (me = math), (iii) how much time each parent spent with their child on math activities, and (iv) the family's socioeconomic status. We found that the frequency with which fathers engaged in home numeracy activities with their daughters had a significant positive effect on their daughters' math self-concept. Interestingly, girls' math self-concepts were also related to socioeconomic status, where girls in lower income families had lower math self-concepts.

We then expanded the study to include children in Grades 1-3. The results showed that at these older ages both boys and girls held the implicit stereotype that math = boys. This is an important timeline because girls, who did not show evidence of stereotypes in kindergarten, nevertheless demonstrated the stereotype in early elementary school. In Grades 1-3, children also expressed a conscious ("explicit") identification with math (math self-concept). Importantly, we found that children who had stronger identification with math also had higher math achievement. This highlights a critical relation between "non-academic" attitudes and beliefs and actual academic achievement.

Beyond our work in Chile, we also formed a collaboration with Croatian scientists to research math attitudes, beliefs, and achievement in a second non-USA country in order to increase our ability to make theoretical and practical generalizations. This study was designed to test: (i) in a different culture and (ii) with an older group of children (Grade 5, in addition to Grade 1). We found that children with more positive math attitudes (math = good) and stronger math self-concepts (math = me) had significantly higher math achievement. Further work in a third country (Spain) also showed that math self-concepts are related to math achievement, and that specially designed intervention strategies may strengthen children's math self-concepts. The results from Croatia and Spain expanded the generalizability of the results by including very different groups of children (South American and Eastern European; Hispanic/Latinx and non-Hispanic/Latinx).

The findings in this project start to form a better picture of when and how children's math attitudes and beliefs develop, and how they relate to math achievement: If parents do not identify with math, it may lead to their children dis-identifying with math, which could in turn lead to lower math achievement. While there are several factors at play in the development of children's attitudes and beliefs, it appears that parents play a significant role, and that girls and boys may be affected differently by their parents.

The results of this project will be particularly interesting to parents, educators, policymakers, and basic research scientists. Parents can use this information to monitor how they express their own math attitudes and beliefs around children. Educators could assess their students' attitudes and beliefs about math with the knowledge that those may actually affect their students' math achievement. Policymakers may want to align governmental and educational policies to consider the role of "non-academic factors" (such as stereotypes, self-concepts, and attitudes) in STEM education. Finally, other scientists can use this project as a model for studying family math attitudes and beliefs in other parts of the world to deepen our understanding of what could be done to increase achievement and equity in math.

The results also have broader impacts. We have already been disseminating these results with families at the largest science museum in the Northwest (Pacific Science Center) through thousands of informal educational opportunities and hands-on participation with our research activities, as well as through meetings with Seattle-area community organizations. Significantly, we have also expanded the reach of these scientific results by creating brief education videos, a free online module, and several infographics designed for the general public to learn more about children's attitudes and beliefs about STEM. These efforts will help us reach our goal of closing the gap between scientific findings and the people whom they could benefit the most.
